>On 9/23/05, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...> wrote:
> >
> >        Yes this is limited in the sense that it makes no provision that the
> > player might be playing against an imperfect opponent, but I see no
> > plausible way to quantify that anyway, e.g. how many ways are there of
> > being "imperfect"?
>
>Well, but that's an important aspect of a good, robust player of any
>game, isn't it?  A very good player of any game will learn to find and
>exploit weakness of an opponent.  If we can't do this at the level of
>Tic-Tac-Toe, what's the point of tackling more difficult games like
>Checkers or Chess or Go?

Hi Derek,

I agree that PPS is far from the whole story, but it's all I know how to do 
at the moment, and I think will be useful as a basis of comparison until 
something better comes along.

e.g.

When we say "let's evolve a player for game X" we are actually being 
ambiguous.  We might mean:

- evolve a player in the context of some opponent(s), or,
- evolve a fixed strategy for the general case of any opponent, or,
- evolve a adaptive strategy that adjusts itself to the current opponent

At the moment I am working on the second of these, and I'll use a lot of 
instances of the first along the way.  But I think the third is too far 
beyond the current state of the art.

PPS is designed as a tool with this in mind.

Note that even a fixed strategy can adapt to things it learns about its 
opponent during a single game, however.

--

The flip side is that I know how to design a definitive score for the 
general case.  But the score against either a fixed opponent, or for a 
system adapting itself to a variable opponent, could only be defined in the 
context of the opponent, and as that opponent will vary from time to time 
and project to project, the score would no longer be useful as a general 
means of comparison.

         Ian


In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
